page.text: 160 W. Santa Clara Street, Suite 675 San Jose CA 95113 (408) 278-1700 Fax (408) 278-1717
Karli Grigsby, David J. Powers & Associates, Inc.
Greg Ripa and Robert Eckols, P.E.

i.b: Finger Avenue Traffic Impact Analysis Peer Review

page.text: This memorandum presents the results of the peer review conducted for the Finger Avenue
. The Finger Avenue Residential project is located
in Redwood City, California. We generally concur with the findings in the analysis, but our
comments below detail a few items that should be addressed prior to finalizing the project
RKH Civil and Transportation Engineering prepared a Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) dated October
January 26, 2011 for the proposed residential subdivision project. The project site is located on
the north side of Finger Avenue and is generally northwest of the intersection of Whipple Avenue
and El Camino Real, in Redwood City, California. The subdivision project consists of replacing
three (3) single-family detached homes and three (3) accessory dwelling units with nine (9)
single-family detached homes (a net increase of three homes).
The study was reviewed for adequacy and appropriateness of project trip generation, distribution,
and assignment, as well as level of service methods and analysis assumptions. The circulation,
parking, and alternative site plan analyses were also reviewed for adequacy and appropriateness.
Generally, the TIA follows industry standards and approaches. The TIA also addresses typical
areas of concern for this type of analysis.
The choice of one study intersection is reasonable due to the small number of net new trips
generated by the proposed development. The RKH report stated that “peak period traffic counts
were taken on Friday, January 7, 2011, from 7:00am to 9:00am and Wednesday, January 5,
2011, from 4:00pm to 6:00pm.” Also, daily (24-hour) traffic counts were taken on Tuesday,
Typically, traffic volumes are not collected on Friday mornings due to possible different trip
characteristics on Fridays versus midweek days (Tuesday through Thursday) when traffic counts
are commonly collected. Since both the morning peak hour counts and the daily (24-hour) counts
were taken during the same week, a comparison was made between the daily counts taken on
Finger Avenue on Tuesday, January 4th and the morning peak hour counts taken on Friday,
January 7th. This comparison showed that the Friday counts were higher than the AM peak hour

text.i: Traffic Impact Analysis Residential Subdivision Finger Avenue Redwood City, California

page.text: Civil and Transportation Engineering and dated January 26, 2011.
volume counted in the 24-hour traffic counts on the Tuesday. Therefore, it is acceptable to use
the Friday morning turning movement volumes since they were higher than the midweek volume.

text.b: TRIP GENERATION, DISTRIBUTION, AND ASSIGNMENT ASSUMPTIONS

page.text: The project trip generation estimates were reviewed and found to be consistent with the single
family dwelling unit rates published in Trip Generation, 8
Engineers (ITE). Lacking trip making characteristics of accessory dwelling units since they are
not shown in the Trip Generation, it is reasonable to estimate the traffic generated by the
secondary dwelling units using the land use category of low rise apartments. The lower rate
would account for these being smaller units than a single family detached unit. The trip
distribution patterns and trip assignment were reviewed and were generally found to be
reasonable based on existing turning movement volumes at the intersection of Finger Avenue / El
Camino Real. In fact, the trip assignment may be conservative since it assumes all of the project
trips would use the Finger Avenue / El Camino Real intersection even though there are potential
alternative routes out of the neighborhood via Hyde Street, Avondale and Edgewood.

text.b: INTERSECTION LEVEL OF SERVICE (LOS) AND QUEUE CALCULATIONS

page.text: Intersection levels of service (LOS) analyses were performed based on the Highway Capacity
, Transportation Research Board, 2000. The TIA assesses project impacts under Existing,
and Existing Plus Project conditions. These two scenarios are reasonable based on the size and
scope of the project. The results of the LOS analysis are reasonable (e.g. they are what would be
expected given the traffic volumes at that intersection) and they show no impact due to the
addition of the project’s peak hour trips.
Queue calculations are based on the methodology presented in the article by John Gard titled

text.i: Estimation of Maximum Queue Lengths at Unsignalized Intersections

page.text: 2001. This method estimates queue lengths based on empirical observations rather than on a
theoretical basis like other queue length estimation methods. Therefore, this method is
reasonable to use in the TIA and the results of the queuing analysis are also reasonable (e.g.
they are what would be expected given the traffic volumes at that intersection) and they show no
impact due to the project’s peak hour trips.
The Traffic Infusion on Residential Environments (TIRE) index is an industry standard practice to
determine the effects a project would have on the surrounding roadway system. Due to the low
trip making characteristics of this development, the increase in the TIRE index of 0.02 is
reasonable (e.g. it is what would be expected given the traffic volumes on Finger Avenue) and
shows no impact due to the project’s daily trips.
The report describes that the on-site access is provided by a roadway that would be between 16
and 18 feet wide on straight sections and approximately 21 feet wide on the curves. There are
four feet of pervious pavers and rolled curbs which would generally be used as a pedestrian
pathway. If needed, large vehicles such as fire trucks and garbage trucks could drive on those
pavers. Therefore, the total width of the roadway available to large vehicles would be between 20
The International Fire Code (IFC), which Redwood City adopted into its Municipal Code (§12),
states that “fire apparatus access roads shall have an unobstructed width of not less than 20 ft”
Therefore, the on-site circulating roadway meets the standard stated in the IFC since the total
width of the roadway (including pavers and curbs) which can be used for emergency vehicles is
between 20 and 22 feet wide. Furthermore, as stated in the article Skinny Streets and Fire
, “outrigger spreads on ladder trucks are typically 16 feet wide. Hence, there is rarely
justification for more than 16 feet of clearance, and in low-rise areas where ladder trucks are
unnecessary, a clear width of 12 feet should suffice.” Thus, although the proposed on-site
roadway width meets IFC standards and should be able to accommodate emergency vehicles,

text.b: we recommend that the report include a discussion about emergency vehicle access and

page.text: The site plan was reviewed to determine the adequacy of the site plan recommendations and to
determine if other recommendations should be made. We concur with the recommendation made
on page 20 of the RKH report regarding one-way operation for the on-site circulation street.
However, during the site plan review, it was determined that the third residence on the right side
of the one-way roadway (see highlighted residence in Figure 1 below) would be difficult to access
due to the acute angle between the one-way circulating roadway and the driveway. Therefore, we
1. Reverse the one-way direction of the on-site circulating roadway from a counter-

text.b: clockwise direction to a clock-wise direction

page.text: (pros and cons of this approach are listed in

roadway (“horseshoe” residence shown in blue on Figure 1) should be reversed and have
the driveway face the other direction (as shown on Figure 2). Note that this home may also
need to be redesigned to fit within the required setbacks and comply with other city
2. Mirror the third home along its lengthwise axis as shown in Figure 2 so that the

text.b: driveway would be closer to the fourth residence rather than the second

page.text: allow for a more perpendicular angle between the one-way circulating roadway and the
driveway). Note that the home may also need to be redesigned to fit within the required
setbacks and comply with other city requirements.

The report states that there are four (4) parking spaces per dwelling unit (two in each garage plus
two on each driveway apron). However, this assumes that each garage would be used for parking
and not for storage or other uses. Therefore, we recommend that the report be revised to

text.b: account for only two spaces per dwelling unit

page.text: . This revision would not alter the conclusions
that the parking provided exceeds the requirements of Redwood City’s Zoning Code or the
estimated demand based on ITE’s Parking Generation. The revised report could state that
although only two spaces are assumed per dwelling unit, the driveway apron may provide
additional parking supply opportunities in addition to the required spaces (garage spaces plus the
The report also states that parking occupancy counts were performed on Finger Avenue in the
vicinity of the project site on one weekday and one weekend day from 6:00am to 8:00pm.
Generally, the highest residential parking demand is in the overnight hours and the parking
counts performed at 6:00am should adequately capture this demand.
Four alternative site plans are discussed in the RKH report.
Like the proposed project, the 9-lot alternatives consist of replacing three (3) single-family
detached homes and three (3) accessory dwelling units with (9) single-family detached homes (a
net increase of three homes). But, instead of locating most homes on a one-way circulating
roadway, most homes would be located off of a two-way dead-end hammerhead roadway that is
24 feet wide. Large vehicle access to homes would require backing maneuvers and all guest
parking would be provided on the driveways of the individual homes. One of the 9-lot alternatives
would have the access roadway located closer to El Camino Real and the other alternative would
have the access roadway located farther from to El Camino Real (closer to Hyde Street).

text.b: We recommend that guest parking be provided along the roadway and that the report
should be updated to include a discussion about parking supply and demand as well as
City parking requirements for this alternative

page.text: . An alternative approach would be to include

text.b: a legal requirement that the garages will only be used for vehicle parking and not storage.

page.text: For example, the report could note that under this alternative, the City Code parking requirements
would still be met and parking demand estimated by ITE’s Parking Generation should be met by
the residence’s garages and the availability of on-street parking since peak on-street demand is
We concur with the discussion regarding truck access and backing maneuvers. Also, we
recommend that the report include a discussion about emergency vehicle access and
This 5-lot alternative consists of replacing three (3) single-family detached homes and three (3)
accessory dwelling units with five (5) single-family detached homes and five (5) accessory
dwelling units (a net increase of four homes). There would not be a circulating roadway in this
alternative. We recommend that the report be updated to include a discussion about

text.b: parking supply and demand as well as City parking requirements.

page.text: could include a statement such as “Each lot would be required to provide at least four parking
spaces to meet the City Code requirements and the parking demand estimates.”
Like the proposed project, this alternative consists of replacing three (3) single-family detached
homes and three (3) accessory dwelling units with (9) single-family detached homes (a net
increase of three homes). But, instead of locating most homes on a one-way circulating roadway,
most homes would be located off of a dead-end hammerhead roadway that is 24 feet wide. We

text.b: recommend that the report be updated to include a discussion about parking supply and
demand as well as City parking requirements.

page.text: For example, the report could include a
statement such as “Each lot would be required to provide at least four parking spaces to meet the
City Code requirements and the parking demand estimates.”
We concur with statements in the report such as “one-way streets are safer than two-way streets
insofar as eliminating head-on or sideswipe crashes.” Furthermore, due to the low traffic volumes
on Finger Avenue and the low trip generation characteristics of the proposed project, there should
not be a substantial change in the safety of the surrounding roadways and the statements made
in the report about safety are reasonable.
We recommend that the traffic study be updated based on the comments shown above in bold
(as well as reprinted below) and be submitted to the City for final review.
The report include a discussion about emergency vehicle access and circulation
The site plan and report be updated so that either:
The one-way direction of the on-site circulating roadway is reversed from a
counter-clockwise direction to a clock-wise direction and the “horseshoe”
residence (shown in blue on Figure 1) should be reversed and have the
driveway face the other direction, OR
The third residence is mirrored along its lengthwise axis (as shown in Figure 2)
so that the residence’s driveway would be nearest to the fourth residence rather
The report should be revised to account for a parking supply based on only two spaces
For the 9-lot alternatives, guest parking should be provided along the roadway, the report
should be updated to include a discussion about parking supply and demand as well as
City parking requirements, and the report should include a discussion about emergency
For the 5- and 4-lot alternatives, the report should be updated to include a discussion
about parking supply and demand as well as City parking requirements.
Peer review of traffic impact analysis, Finger Avenue subdivision, Redwood City
The following are my responses to the comments presented in a memo dated April 13, 2011,
from Greg Ripa and Robert Eckols of Fehr & Peers to Karli Grigsby at David J. Powers &
Include a discussion about emergency vehicle access and circulation.
The roadways in the proposed subdivision and its alternatives meet the Redwood City Municipal
Code requirement of an unobstructed width of 20 feet. The plans have been reviewed and
approved by the Redwood City Fire Department. I see no need for additional discussion in the
Acute angle of third residence on the right side - difficult access.
Using the “P” design vehicle turning template, Exhibit 2-3, as shown in the AASHTO
publication, “A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets,” a passenger car can
easily enter the driveway as designed. If the driver wishes to enter only on the right side of the
driveway a small flare of the driveway at the street would solve the problem. There is no need to
reverse the layout of the home on the lot, to reverse the circulation of the street from
counterclockwise to clockwise, or to make the street a 2-way street to accommodate vehicle
The Redwood City Zoning Code, Article 30.4 , requires single family dwellings of 4 or fewer
bedrooms to have two covered parking spaces and accessory buildings to have one uncovered
space. The peer reviewer suggests to assume that the garages would not be used for vehicle
parking but rather for storage and to alter the report accordingly. In my professional opinion
837 C olum ba Lane • Foster C ity, C A 94404 • (650)212-0837 • FAX(650)212-3150
such a statement is inappropriate and without substantiation. The traffic and parking analysis
has to be based on the facts of the City’s legal requirements for the subdivision, the conditions of
the surrounding neighborhood with respect to on-street parking, and the provisions of the
subdivision design to meet the anticipated parking demand. According to the 4 edition of
Parking Generation, ITE © 2010, the peak parking demand for the nine lot subdivision is on the
order of 21 vehicles on a weekday. That averages out to 2.2 vehicles per dwelling. To my
knowledge there is little in the way of parking generation data to support the notion that single
family dwellings need more than the typical 2-car garage. In the proposed subdivision each
dwelling has a 2-car garage and a driveway of sufficient length to accommodate two additional
vehicles. Additionally, there are to be five parking spaces provided for visitors along the private
street for a parking potential of 41 vehicles.
The parking demand for the 9-lot alternatives would be no different than for the proposed
subdivision except that three of the lots will front onto Finger Avenue directly and the remaining
six lots will be served from a hammerhead cul-de-sac street. The six lots served by the cul-de-
sac street are sufficiently deep that parking for additional vehicles would be no different than for
the proposed subdivision. There is no provision in the Redwood City Zoning Code to provide
visitor parking for single family dwelling units. For multiple dwelling units, condominiums and
townhouses there is a provision in §30.4-A.5. of the code to provide one visitor parking space for
every four dwelling units. Because the plan will cause the loss of three parking spaces on Finger
Avenue the argument could be made to make up for the loss of that parking and to provide three
visitor spaces on the cul-de-sac street. However, because of the configuration of the hammer-
head cul-de-sac, the narrowness of five of the six lots, and the angle of the lot lines at the street,
provision for visitor parking would be problematic at best. It would be better to accommodate
visitor parking for these lots on the driveways of the individual dwellings.
Emergency vehicles as well as moving vans and service vehicles would have full access to the
lots served by the private hammerhead cul-de-sac street. The hammerhead turnout meets the
dimensional requirements of Attachment P of the City’s Engineering Design Criteria for fire
The matter of parking supply and demand for the 5-lot alternative is no different than for the
proposed project or the other alternatives. The five lots are sufficiently deep that the buildings
can be set back sufficiently from the street so that the driveways could easily accommodate at
least two visitor vehicles in addition to the two required covered parking spaces for the single
family dwelling and the one uncovered parking space for the cottage. This alternative would
result in the loss of only one parking space on Finger Avenue. With the maximum on-street
parking demand found to be less than 60% of the supply, there is no justification to require
The parking supply and demand for this alternative is basically the same as for the 5-lot
alternative except in this alternative there is no loss of on-street parking supply on Finger
Avenue. The lots are sufficiently deep to allow the dwellings to be set back from the street so
that two additional vehicles could be parked on the driveways in addition to the required on-site
I trust these responses satisfactorily address the peer review comments. If you have any
questions or need further clarification of my responses, please feel free to call me or e-mail me
